questions.text: Which is the correct ratio for acute hypovolemic coagulopathy requiring massive transfusion?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is a: 1 RBCC: 1 plasma: 0.25 platelet concentrate

For massive transfusion for bleeding patients 6 units of packed RBC, 6 units of fresh frozen plasma and 6 units of platelet rich plasma should be given in ratio 1:1:1.

Now one unit of platelet concentrate/ Single donor platelet = 4-6 units of platelet rich plasma which changes the ratio of 1:1:0.25 as given in the question above.

questions.text: Which transfusion reaction is most strongly associated with HLA antibodies in donor plasma?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is a: TRALI

TRALI (Transfusion-Related Acute Lung Injury) is most strongly linked to anti-HLA or anti-HNA antibodies in donor plasma.

These antibodies bind to the recipient’s leukocytes causing neutrophil activation in lung capillaries and resultant non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema. It has a typical onset: within 6 hours of transfusion.

Prevention of TRALI : Use plasma from male donors or screen multiparous women for HLA antibodies.

questions.text: 30-year-old man receives a unit of O⁺ packed RBCs. Within 10 minutes, he develops fever, chills, hypotension, and flank pain. Which investigation will be most specific for confirming the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is b: Direct antiglobulin Coombs test

  • In acute hemolytic transfusion reaction, the Direct Antiglobulin Test (DAT) detects antibodies or complement bound to RBCs in vivo. It is the most specific for confirming immune-mediated hemolysis after transfusion.

questions.text: The patient is started on blood transfusion in a post operative room and within 5 minutes you notice that the patient develops a rash all over the body with cold clammy extremities. pulse is 120/min, BP is 80/60 mm Hg with inspiratory rhonchi in bilateral lungs The blood group of the patient is 0+ and the patient was given 0+ blood as verified by the blood bank. Which of the following is the first differential diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is b: Anaphylaxis

Some IgA-deficient individuals develop anti-IgA antibodies (often IgE type).

This happens because their immune system sees IgA as a foreign antigen — they’ve never been tolerized to it.

Development of rash + Hypotension + Bronchospasm indicates anaphylaxis.

questions.text: Which of the following blood components has the highest chances of causing transfusion transmitted infection?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is a: Platelet concentrate

Platelets are stored at room temperature (20–24 °C) with constant agitation.

This environment is ideal for bacterial growth if contamination occurs during collection or processing.

Even a small number of bacteria introduced during venipuncture or processing can multiply rapidly during the 3–7 days of storage.

questions.text: Which of the following is not correct about usage and storage of blood components?

choices.text: Packed RBC can be stored for up to 42 days at 4 C
Platelets can be stored for 3-7 days at 20-24 C
Granulocyte concentrate at room temperature and used within 24 hours of end of collection
Plasma is cryopreserved at -4 C and should be used within 1 hours of thawing

questions.solution:
Correct answer is d: Plasma is cryopreserved at -4 C and should be used within 1 hours of thawing

  • Plasma is cryopreserved at -18 C and should be used within 6 hours of thawing to preserve maximum labile factor activity ( factor V and Factor VIII activity)

questions.text: Deleucocytation is defined as ?

choices.text: <1–5. 106 leukocytes per unit of blood components
<1–5.  107 leukocytes per unit of blood components
<1–5. 108 leukocytes per unit of blood components
<1–5. 109 leukocytes per unit of blood components

questions.solution:
Correct answer is A: <1–5. 106 leukocytes per unit of blood components

  • Deleucocytation is defined as < 1–5. 104 leukocytes per unit of blood component and reduces incidence of complications like FNHTR and alloimmunization.

questions.text: High efficiency deleucocytation is being done using the filter shown in the image. It will reduce all of the following complications of blood transfusion except?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is a: Mismatched blood transfusion

Mismatched blood transfusion is an ABO/Rh incompatibility reaction caused by recipient antibodies attacking donor RBC antigens. It is usually a clerical error and cannot be prevented by performing deleucocytation.

High-efficiency deleucocytation filters remove WBCs, so they prevent complications caused by donor leukocytes, such as:

  1. Febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reaction (due to cytokines from WBCs)
  2. CMV transmission (CMV resides in WBC)
  3. HLA alloimmunization (immune sensitization to leukocyte antigens)
  4. Reduction of transfusion transmitted infections

questions.text: Which of the following is immunodominant sugar in patient with blood group A
questions.solution:
Correct answer is b: N-acetyl- galactosamine

Blood group antigens are determined by specific terminal sugars attached to the H antigen on RBC membranes.

Group A : Enzyme adds N-acetyl-galactosamine to H antigen.

Group B : Enzyme adds galactose to H antigen

Group AB: Enzyme adds both of the above to H antigen

Group O : No additional sugar (H antigen remains as fucose-based structure).

questions.text: Which of the following blood groups is a universal plasma donor?
questions.solution:
Correct answer c: AB

Group AB plasma has no anti-A and no anti-B antibodies and hence it can be given to recipients of any blood group without causing hemolysis.

Universal RBC donor = O negative (Rationale: It has no A/B/D antigens on RBCs)

Universal plasma donor = AB (Rationale: no A/B antibodies in plasma)

questions.text: An unbooked 30 year old multigravida in the 36 weeks of pregnancy is having severe anemia with Hb of 6.8 gm/dl. She was prescribed 2 units of PRBC . She develops high grade fever 40 C with chills and rigors, hypotension and bleeding from IV cannula site 1 hour after completion of transfusion. Diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is c: Transfusion transmitted bacterial infection

  • Contaminated PRBC (often with gram-negative bacteria like Yersinia enterocolitica or Serratia) can cause sudden high fever (>39–40 °C), chills, hypotension, and DIC (hence bleeding from IV site). Symptoms often appear during or shortly after transfusion completion. Diagnosis is transfusion transmitted infection.

Incorrect Options:

Mismatched Blood Transfusion :Usually starts during transfusion (not after completion) with fever, chills, back pain, dark urine, hypotension. Bleeding from the iv site due to DIC can occur but timing favours the above mentioned diagnosis.

Febrile Non-Hemolytic Transfusion Reaction :It has no hypotension, no DIC, and no severe sepsis-like picture.

TRALI presents with acute respiratory distress, hypoxemia, and bilateral pulmonary infiltrates within 6 hours.

questions.text: “Lethal triad of death” includes
questions.solution:
Correct answer is a: Acidosis, hypothermia and coagulopathy

Lethal triad of death in trauma patients consists of-

  • Hypothermia – cooling from exposure, shock, and infusion of cold fluids/blood.
  • Acidosis – from hypoperfusion, anaerobic metabolism, and lactate buildup.
  • Coagulopathy – from consumption of clotting factors, dilution by fluids, and hypothermia-induced enzyme dysfunction.

questions.text:
Which of the following complications can occur after multiple blood transfusions?

1. Hypokalemia

2. Hyperkalemia

3. Hypocalcemia

4. Metabolic acidosis
questions.solution:
Correct answer is c: 1,2,3

Hyperkalemia can be seen immediately after multiple transfusions due to K rich supernatant fluid. Reason is RBC membrane Na⁺/K⁺-ATPase pump fails over time because the RBCs run out of ATP.

Hypokalemia occurs after a few hours to days after blood transfusion as RBC will glucose from the recipient blood stream. Beside the metabolic alkalosis due to citrate excess will also cause hypokalemia. Remember potassium and pH of blood have an inverse relation.

Hypocalcemia can be explained by citrate excess. Citrate excess causes metabolic alkalosis.

questions.text: Cryoprecipitate can be used in all of the following cases except

choices.text: Haemophilia A in absence of factor VIII concentrate
Hemophilia B in absence of factor IX concentrate

questions.solution:
Correct answer is d: Hemophilia B in absence of factor IX concentrate

Cryoprecipitate is rich in Factor VIII, vWF, fibrinogen, Factor XIII but lacks factor 9. So it would not be useful to control bleeding in a patient with Hemophilia B.

Von Willebrand disease type II has quality and type III has quantitative issues that can be managed with cryoprecipitate

This question is more theory oriented as we avoid using cryoprecipitate due to risk of transmission of infection.

questions.text: Platelet concentrate is given below which threshold in a patient in absence of fever or infection
questions.solution:
Correct answer is B: < 5,000 / uL

Threshold of platelet transfusion

In absence of fever or infection

<5,0000 / uL

If fever or infection

<10,000 / uL

If surgery planned, DIC, endoscopy or invasive procedure

< 50,000 / uL

If neurosurgery or eye surgery

< 80,000 / uL

questions.text: R.T.A victim was given 6 units of whole blood in the last 6 hours. Which of the following complications is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is c: Hypocalcemia

  • In massive transfusion (>1 blood volume in 24 hrs or >2.5L in 6 hours), the amount of citrate infused can overwhelm the liver’s ability to metabolize it. Citrate binds ionized calcium, leading to hypocalcemia. This manifests as hypotension, prolonged QT interval, paresthesias, tetany, and bleeding (due to impaired clotting factor function).

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with C.K.D on maintenance hemodialysis presents with severe anemia (Hb 6.9 g/dL) and is transfused with 2 units of packed red blood cells over 4 hours. Shortly after the transfusion, he develops acute shortness of breath. On examination, he has elevated jugular venous pressure, bilateral basal crackles, and blood pressure of 180/100 mmHg. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is b: Transfusion -associated circulatory overload

TACO is seen in elderly, CKD, and heart failure patients after rapid/high-volume transfusion. Presents with acute pulmonary edema, elevated JVP, hypertension, and positive fluid balance.

Raised JVP and hypertension point away from TRALI.

FNHTR is characterized by fever and chills during/after transfusion due to cytokine release.

questions.text: A 30 year old woman on steroids for SLE had received one unit of blood transfusion after her recent delivery of a healthy boy baby. 10 days later she developed fever, rashes and diarrhea. Which complication of blood transfusion would you suspect?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is b: Graft versus host disease

  • This question can be solved by time lag after blood transfusion that has caused manifestations. Option A,C,D will occur during or immediately after the transfusion.
  • GVHD is mediated by donor T lymphocytes in a recipient unable to reject such allogenic lymphocytes like severely immunosuppressed patients.

Donor T lymphocytes interact with host HLA Ags and mount an immune response, which occurs 5–10 days after transfusion and causes the following:

  1. Fever, Cytopenia,
  2. Characteristic skin rash
  3. Diarrhea and liver function abnormalities.

questions.text: Which of the following is not correct about TRALI

choices.text: Donor antibodies bind to recipient neutrophils in pulmonary endothelium causing release or pro inflammatory cytokines
Usually occurs within 6 hours of transfusion
Bilateral interstitial infiltrates due to cardiogenic pulmonary edema
Reduced incidence by taking plasma from only male donor

questions.solution:
Correct answer is c: Bilateral interstitial infiltrates due to cardiogenic pulmonary edema

TRALI Is non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema. It occurs due to

  1. Transfusion of donor plasma containing high-titer anti-HLA class II Abs that bind recipient cognate Ag.
  2. Anti-HLA class I and anti–human neutrophil antigen

The damage to pulmonary endothelium makes it leaky and causes fluid to leak out into alveoli. It is more common in the first 6 hours but can occur up to 72 hours.

questions.text: The leading cause of death due to blood transfusion is?
questions.solution: Correct answer is a: TACO
